On Tue, 23 May 2023 19:48:54 +0000, Cmcculloch emailed Agwhaley regarding "Re: 410220052":

Cc: [cwelch@rmsc.com](mailto:cwelch@rmsc.com) Chris Welch, [jessa@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:jessa@whaleylawfirm.com) Jessa Galosmo, [justin@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:justin@whaleylawfirm.com) Justin Chumbley, [BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com)
The police report states ?Unit #1 (your client) stated the same about where she was coming from and what direction she was going but seemed confused about where #2 (our truck) came from.? Our truck was a Ford F450 which is nearly 20 feet long and ways over 4 tons and she hit it. How can she be confused about here such a large truck came from before hitting it unless she was not paying attention to where she was going? If she missed a 4 ton truck, a small thing like what color the light was at the time would be an easy thing to miss. This scenario seems most likely but, as I said, I can?t prove it and need to in order to assert a claim. We are willing to review any evidence you have that would establish the light color but will not agree to pay a claim when the only participants have opposing accounts and the only witnesses are both not disinterested 3rd parties.
Clarke McCulloch
Property & Casualty Claims Manager
From: Aaron Whaley
To: Clarke McCulloch
Cc: Chris Welch ; Jessa Galosmo ; Justin Chumbley ; BrendaLangMVAZ3760694@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com
Clarke, testimony is proof. It would be up to the jury who to believe. They could believe based upon your driver and passenger that Ms. Lang ran the light. They could believe Ms. Lang that your insured turned right on red.

Clarke, according to the accident report it says that the damage to my
client's car is at 1:00 which would be the passenger front and the damage
to your vehicle is at 11:00 which is the drivers front. Seems to me your
guy didn't get very far into his turn before the impact. The report
doesn't tell us who hit whom. Certainly with the impact where it was there
was no time for my client to see or appreciate a 20 foot long vehicle. I
have litigated many cases just like this and I am fine doing it again.
There is more than one way to do this. I am good either way.

episode_body:
Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021
Client: Brenda Lang

Had client and defendant depos today. Client's depo went pretty poorly as she had a ton of trouble explaining how the collision occurred and changed her story a couple of times, at one point testifying that the vehicle in the damage photos was not the vehicle she collided with - very difficult. However, the Defendant testified that he could not remember anything about the collision (where he was coming from, going to, what street he was on when the wreck occurred). The police report and incident reports by driver and passenger contradict one another. Spoke to DC and said I would be sending over a demand soon. He candidly told me they would likely make a small offer but are not going to accept the appendectomy as related (2 days post-MVA). I told him I would send him over a demand with everything and we can talk numbers in the future.

Case: Brenda-Lang-MVA-09-03-2021

__Summary of the call with Brenda D. Long__
Hi
Here's the summary of the call with Brenda D. Long at 1/10 11:30 AM
(UTC-05:00):
Brenda and Aaron discussed the challenges in proving the appendicitis was
related to the car accident, leading to a recommendation to negotiate a
settlement.
Recap
 * Aaron Whaley informed Brenda that the demand sent for her car accident
case has not been accepted due to difficulties in linking her appendicitis
to the accident.
 * The accident occurred on September 3rd, and Brenda went to the emergency
room two days later.
 * Aaron reviewed medical records and found insufficient evidence to prove
the appendicitis was caused by the accident, despite the timing.
 * Brenda acknowledged the truck hit her car but expressed frustration over
the opposing party's stance.
 * Aaron recommended starting negotiations with the other party, as
pursuing the appendicitis claim would likely be unproductive.
 * Brenda expressed gratitude for Aaron's support during this challenging
time, especially after losing her husband.
Tasks
 * Aaron needs to initiate negotiations with the opposing attorney
regarding the settlement offer.
Best,
aaron whaley

Good afternoon Mr. Gowen,
I hope this email finds you well. Attached, please find a revised
settlement demand for the above-referenced matter.
As you will see, we have removed all references to the appendix-related
issues and treatment. While we continue to believe there were valid
questions regarding the connection of those issues to the collision, we
recognize the difficulty in litigating such matters. This removal is
intended as a showing of good faith to help facilitate a resolution in this
case.
Even with those items removed, Ms. Lang has incurred more than $26,000 in
medical expenses directly related to the injuries caused by your client's
negligence. As such, an offer in the range of $5,000-10,000 will not be
sufficient to resolve this matter.
We remain willing to discuss a reasonable resolution based on the
documented medical expenses and Ms. Lang's pain and suffering. Please let
us know your client's position after reviewing the revised demand and
supporting materials.
Thank you for your time and consideration. We look forward to hearing from
you.
